title: ripemdhash
author: ripemdhash
content: Hello, I am a new user of this forum. However, before registering, I have been reading various posts related to technical issues for a long time. I'm very curious if anyone has managed to find a collision in RIPEMD160 on Bitcoin addresses. Are there any known collision data with public keys, and if possible, with private keys as well?

comments.author: GR Sasa
comments.body: shortest answer that you'll ever hear in your life.no

comments.author: vjudeu
comments.body: You can just watch 3KyiQEGqqdb4nqfhUzGKN6KPhXmQsLNpay address from this puzzle. As long as those coins are here, you can be quite sure that there are no collisions. And you can always add more coins to be sure that people have enough incentive to share such collisions.

comments.author: ripemdhash
comments.created_time: June 23, 2023, 07:41:39 PMLast edit: June 23, 2023, 07:52:06 PM by ripemdhash
comments.body: 1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSo Â - after hash160 -> Â c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf4409821GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk - after hash160 -> c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf4409821LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sE - after hash160 -> c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf440982hash160 -> sha 256 with ripemd160of course after it is real address "1JyCwfjA8jYwMxcf6E7DXSs6rpcnZ2uppi"it is collision? in sha256 or in ripemd160?

comments.author: PawGo
comments.body: Quote from: ripemdhash on June 23, 2023, 07:41:39 PM1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSoÂ  - after hash160 ->Â  c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf4409821GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk - after hash160 -> c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf4409821LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sE - after hash160 -> c51b66bced5e4491001bd702669770dccf440982I am not sure what you wanted to show, but it completely makes no sense for me. Could you explain step by step?Quote from: ripemdhash on June 23, 2023, 03:16:04 PMI am a new user of this forum. However, before registering, I have been reading various posts related to technical issues for a long time. I'm very curious if anyone has managed to find a collision in RIPEMD160 on Bitcoin addresses. Are there any known collision data with public keys, and if possible, with private keys as well?Some scientific progress has been made (https://eprint.iacr.org/2023/285) but it is still very far from a simple every-day use. In other words - RIPEMD160 is still secure.

comments.author: ripemdhash
comments.created_time: June 23, 2023, 08:01:48 PMLast edit: June 23, 2023, 08:12:00 PM by ripemdhash
comments.body: input to sha256:1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSo1GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk1LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sEoutput of sha256:4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459aso it is collisions on sha256:)am I first?Is any reward for finding collision on sha256?

comments.author: garlonicon
comments.body: Quote4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459aThis value is just SHA-256 for "01" byte. That means you are calling SHA-256 on different data than you think.QuoteIs any reward for finding collision on sha256?You can try to spend coins from 35Snmmy3uhaer2gTboc81ayCip4m9DT4ko, but then you need two values: providing "01" byte alone is not sufficient.

comments.author: witcher_sense
comments.body: Quote from: ripemdhash on June 23, 2023, 08:01:48 PMinput to sha256:1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSo1GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk1LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sEoutput of sha256:4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459aso it is collisions on sha256:)am I first?Is any reward for finding collision on sha256?You are the first who calculated sha256 hash incorrectly 3 times in a row.Code:~ $ echo -n 1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSo | sha256sum42ba835e9f265ec93bc684ea0ddc40d08dfbe1e73c52eaf91248219135bb46d2Â  -~ $ echo -n 1GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk | sha256sum0be415623f3adca5d958654df19e19ecf60fd25aa31b1b1b44bb41a8cdae2b7cÂ  -~ $ echo -n 1LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sE | sha256sumd08bd4cf1aaafbf137a42350170d3e7fb127655dcd0edbc26dae683eba8193cc

comments.author: ymgve2
comments.body: Quote from: ripemdhash on June 23, 2023, 08:01:48 PMinput to sha256:1NqyFopy2LAghcL4o5xjiuSaRFo3KoPNSo1GVXnKbEbcuUAB6iF2dvgVTUKQwpZ2NpUk1LRhnNWHoAfLjVZe51XXMYCuBJmvPvE1sEoutput of sha256:4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459a4bf5122f344554c53bde2ebb8cd2b7e3d1600ad631c385a5d7cce23c7785459aso it is collisions on sha256:)am I first?Is any reward for finding collision on sha256?your sha256/ripemd160 library is expecting a hexadecimal input, and stops on the first non-hex character it encounters. they all start with "1" then a non-hex char so they all have the "same" "hash"

comments.author: digaran
comments.body: Look, stop mixing things, you could hash whatever you want and extract addresses from them, I even found an address with more than 70 BTC balance, it has a colliding RMD hash.When I was working on hashes, I found so many interesting things, like hashing an address with SHA-256 and then RMD-160 to arrive at the same address again, can't recall exactly, when I have the time to go through my laptop files, I will show you so many things, like finding your desired checksum using WIFsolver tool etc.Take this address, 12zqc8j8Btu8fvDbTTky9PXEMkd9ub5K5sPerform SHA-256 on the first 2 characters "12" and Perform RMD-160 on the hash 256 then convert to address, you will see the same address, coincidence? Definitely.Hash 160 (sha256+rmd160) of (converted to address)12 = 12zqc8j8Btu8fvDbTTky9PXEMkd9ub5K5s14 = 16gbG4hC3sTsZXn47KG6uWcjN8ww6EB5XiHere, a magic trick!Â  Just perform sha256 on the following addressÂ  ,12noFjFNrtaCcBDMZ5ZMpJQbUPLD4MGpL6 or "12"Â  3 times, then use the third hash as private key to generate uncompressed address, tell me what you see? ðŸ˜‰ this happens when you mix base58, rmd160, sha256 and secp256k1. Totally normal, I was so excited first when I discovered all of these, now I spend my time on the real deal stuff (public keys + & - ). ðŸ™‚

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: Quote from: digaran on June 24, 2023, 03:28:27 AMPerform SHA-256 on the first 2 characters "12" and Perform RMD-160 on the hash 256 then convert to address, you will see the same address, coincidence? Definitely.Most probably this is not a coincidence or a collision for that matter. Considering the addresses you shared were never spent from they could be categorized as addresses that were created from the hash like some sort of silly puzzle not from a public key. In other words nobody can spend these coins because they don't have the key, they just did what you did (hashed 2 characters and then created that address).Something like this:Code:for (chars from 0x10 to 0x1f)Â  hash = compute(Base16.Decode(0x+chars))Â  address = encode(hash)Â  if (address[1..2] == chars)Â  Â  print (address)Â  Â  burn_coins_by_sending_to(address)
